description: From French prestige (“illusion, fascination, enchantment, prestige”), from Latin praestigium (“a delusion, an illusion”). Despite the phonetic similarities and the old meaning of “delusion, illusion, trick”, the word has a different root than prestidigitator (“conjurer”) and prestidigitation.

entries.meaning: (sociolinguistics, of a linguistic form) Regarded as relatively prestigious; often, considered the standard language or language variety, or a part of such a variety.
The quality of how good the reputation of something or someone is, how favourably something or someone is regarded.
examples: Oxford has a university of very high prestige.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, often preceded by "the") Delusion; illusion; trick.

verbs.description: prestige (third-person singular simple present prestiges, present participle prestiging, simple past and past participle prestiged)

entries.meaning: (video games) To start over at an earlier point in a video game with some type of bonus or reward.
